title: A mixture of 40 litres of milk and water contains 10% water. How much water should be added so that the water is 20% in the new mixture? - Quora

response.answer_text: 40 liters of milk-water mixture contains 10% water. So it contains 90% milk.So amount of milk in the mixture= 40 x0.9=36 liter.Now on adding 'X' liters of water the % of water increases to 20% . Or the % of milk decreases to 80% .So (40+X) x 0.8= 36.So upon solving the equation 32+0.8X =36 (or)0.8X=36–32=4.So X= 4/0.8= 5So on adding 5 liters of water to the above milk-water mixture the new milk-water mixture will contain 20% water. ==============================Another Simple Method:40- Litres 90% pure milk is to be diluted to 80% pure- milk.So 40 X 0.9 = V x 0.8,[where “V”- is the volume of milk containing 20% water= 80%- milk. ]Upon solving the equation we get V= 45- Litres.So on adding (45–40)= 5- Litres of water to 40- Litres of 90% milk we will get 45- Litres of 80% - milk.OK.++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Solve this question by fraction   Without using x solution Explanation- Mixture given = 40L 10% of which was water. So remaining 90% was milk. Now we have to increase the water percentage to 20%. Therefore the milk percentage in new mixture is 80%. In ratio, it becomes 4:1. Lets say we added ‘x’ litres of water in the mixture and quantity of milk remains constant throughout. So, x=5L of water must be added in the mixture to make water 20% in new mixture.

I do not understand your notation of “contain 108/6 water”. Please reformulate your question and resubmit.’ Edit: That’s better. Well, clearly 10% of anything is the same thing as saying 1/10 of it, and 1/10 of 40 liters is clearly 4 L. Since you want to increase the proportion that is water from 10% to 20%, the naïve person would say you’re doubling the amount of water, so you have to add another 4 L of water. This would be wrong. Since every bit of water you add is also changing the total volume of the mixure, adding 4 L to 40 L would result in 44 L of mixture, 8 L of which would be water, giving a proportion of 8 / 44 = 18.(18) %. Not a high enough proportion. What you want is for the proportion of the quantity of the original amount of water plus the added amount of water divided by the quantity of the original amount of mixture plus the added amount of water is equal to 20%. An easier formulation of 20% for such algebra would be 1/5. (4+x)÷(40+x)=1/5(4+x)÷(40+x)=1/5 Solving for x is left as an exercise for the reader.

This can be solved using Principle of Alligation. The question, if carefully read, also means what quantity of 100% water solution should be mixed with 10% water solution to get 20% water solution.  The ratio of 10% water solution and pure water should be 80:10 or 8:1 Now, 40L of 10% water solution represents 8 parts of total quantity in new solution. Therefore, 1 part is 40/8 = 5L So, 5L of pure water is to be added.

5 litres. 10% of 40 litres is 4 litres.To make it 20% water, you'll have to add 'x' litres of water to the mixture. (x+4)/(x+40) = 20/100x+4 = (x+40)0.2x+4 = 0.2x+80.8x = 4x = 4/0.8x = 5 So, if you add 5 litres of water to the mixture, you'll have 20% of water in the 45 litres of mixture, i.e., 9 litres.

In 40 liters of milk-water mixture, the water content is 4 liters. By adding x liters of water the water content should become 20 %. (4+x)/(40+x) = 20/100, or 100(4+x) = 20(40+x), or 400 - 800 = 20–100x, or 400 = 80x, or x = 5 liters. So add 5 liters water to make the milk-water mixture more dilute to the extent of 20% water. Check:(4+5):(40+5) = 9/45 = 1/5 or 20 percent. Correct.

Its quite simple, add 5l of water In current mixture there is 1o% water & 90 % MILK Thus the mixture of 40 L has : 4L of water and 36L of milk.Let Y= amount of water present in final solution.Now 36+Y=total volume of final solutionthat means 20% of (36+Y) = Y0.2(36 +Y)=Y36+Y=5Y4Y=36Y=9There was 4L of water already there, So you need to mix another 5 litres. Other way round :Z=total volume of final solution.So water present in it will be Z-36Thus Z-36=20% of ZZ-36=0.2Z0.8Z=36Z=45Difference= 45-40=5L

it’s very simple… old mixture = 40L old water = 0.1(40) = 4L let x be the amount of water to be added to the old mixture so new amount of mixture becomes new mixture amount =(40 + x) ……….. eq1 also new amount of water = (4+x) ……… eq2 given that new amount of water is 20% of new mixture so from eq1 and eq2 => 4+x = 0.2(40 + x) => 4+x = 8+0.2x => x-0.2x=8–4 => 0.8x=4 => x = amount of water to be added = 5L

Answer: 5 litresOne easy way of solving this problem has already been posted.Here's another:In current mixture there is 4L of water and 36L of milk.We take x= water present in final solution.Now 36+x=total volume of final solutionthat means 20% of (36+x) = x0.2(36 +x)=x36+x=5x4x=36x=9Since there was 4L of water already there, you need to add another 5 litres. One more way:x=total volume of final solution.So water present in it will be x-36Thus x-36=20% of xx-36=0.2x0.8x=36x=45Difference= 45-40=5LSince we took the volume of milk as a fixed 36 litres, an extra 5 litres of water has to be added.
Initialy M : w 90% : 10% later 80% : 20% (Diff in % * total Mixture)/( Later % of liquid that doesn’t change) (10*40)/80 = 5L

Simple way total volume of mix containing 90 percent milk(10 percent water). = 40 lt Milk content in mix = 40*0.9= 36 lt. Milk content will remain same ,water can be added to mix. New volume of mix containing 20 percent water =36*100/80=45 lt. More water to be added =45 -40= 5 lt.

40 litres of mixture has 10% of water = 4 litres of water 4 litres of water is 10% in 40 litres. If you add another 4 litres (10%) in 40 litres, volume will increase to 44 litres but water will be 8 litres but the percentage will be 18.18 %. If you add 5 litres of water, new volume will be 45 litres water will be 9 litres = 20% of water.
The mixture contains milk + water = 40liters 10% of this mixture is water. Or 40*(10/100) liters of water is in the mixture = 4 liters. If 10% of mixture is 4, then 20% = 5liters

40 liter of milk contains 10% water means 36 ltr milk + 4 ltr water If want to make existing solution to 20% then you have to add more 5 ltr water.new volume become 45 ltr that contains 36 ltr water + 9 ltr water If you want to make 40 ltr total volume that contains 20% water then you have to mix 32 ltr milk with 8 ltr water.

40 litre mixture of milk and water contains 10% water that means it has 4 litres of water. Let x litres of water is added to get a mixture containing 20% water. So, 20% of (40+x) litres = 4+x Or, (40+x)/5 = 4+x Or, 40+x = 20+5x So, x= 5 Hence, required amount of water is 5 litres.

This is a deceptive question as milk is a mixture of water, oils, fats, and proteins. Since the percentage of water in the milk is not stated the answer to the question can only provide a range at best.

A mixture of 40 liters of milk = 36 liters of Milk and 4 liters of water = 90:10 ratioNow the new mixture should be in the ratio of 80:20Hence 80% is equivalent to 36 liters (no addition of milk is done)100% is (36/80)*100 = 45 liters of milk is present in the new mixtureThus water shall be added= (45 – 36 – 4) = 5 liters of water
Five liters must be added for the new mixture to be 20% water. x = 40 + y 0.2x = 4 + y x = 20 + 5y 20 + 5y = 40 + y 4y = 20 y = 5 (amount added) x = 45 (new total volume)
Use Rule of allegation for such problems
36L=80% of new mixture 1% of new mixture=36/80 100% of new mixture=(36/80)×100 45L we got new mixture So ans is 45 -40=5 L

x=total volume of final solution.So water present in it will be x-36Thus x-36=20% of xx-36=0.2x0.8x=36x=45Difference= 45-40=5LSince we took the volume of milk as a fixed 36 litres, an extra 5 litres of water has to be added.
If this is a theoretical mathematical question, then it's ok. :). Otherwise milk contains about 87% water naturally. So, 40 litres milk would contain about 35 litres of water.
